arcade.Collidable.name: Collidable
arcade.Collidable.description: Any class implementing this interface can be used on World.collide()

arcade.Extensions.name: Extensions
arcade.Extensions.description: A bunch of static extensions to make life easier.

arcade.SortBodiesBottomTop.name: SortBodiesBottomTop
arcade.SortBodiesBottomTop.description:
SortBodiesBottomTop provides a stable implementation of merge sort through its sort
method. It should be used instead of Array.sort in cases where the order
of equal elements has to be retained on all targets.

arcade.SortBodiesLeftRight.name: SortBodiesLeftRight
arcade.SortBodiesLeftRight.description:
SortBodiesLeftRight provides a stable implementation of merge sort through its sort
method. It should be used instead of Array.sort in cases where the order
of equal elements has to be retained on all targets.

arcade.SortBodiesRightLeft.name: SortBodiesRightLeft
arcade.SortBodiesRightLeft.description:
SortBodiesLeftRight provides a stable implementation of merge sort through its sort
method. It should be used instead of Array.sort in cases where the order
of equal elements has to be retained on all targets.

arcade.SortBodiesTopBottom.name: SortBodiesTopBottom
arcade.SortBodiesTopBottom.description:
SortBodiesTopBottom provides a stable implementation of merge sort through its sort
method. It should be used instead of Array.sort in cases where the order
of equal elements has to be retained on all targets.

ceramic.AntialiasedTriangle.name: AntialiasedTriangle
ceramic.AntialiasedTriangle.description: A variant of Triangle using a bit more vertices to simulate antialiasing (without multisampling)

ceramic.App.name: App
ceramic.App.description: App class is the root instance of any ceramic app.

ceramic.Arc.name: Arc
ceramic.Arc.description: Convenience mesh subclass to draw arc, pie, ring or disc geometry

ceramic.ArcadeSortGroupBottomTop.name: ArcadeSortGroupBottomTop
ceramic.ArcadeSortGroupBottomTop.description:
ArcadeSortGroupBottomTop provides a stable implementation of merge sort through its sort
method. It should be used instead of Array.sort in cases where the order
of equal elements has to be retained on all targets.

ceramic.ArcadeSortGroupLeftRight.name: ArcadeSortGroupLeftRight
ceramic.ArcadeSortGroupLeftRight.description:
ArcadeSortGroupLeftRight provides a stable implementation of merge sort through its sort
method. It should be used instead of Array.sort in cases where the order
of equal elements has to be retained on all targets.

ceramic.ArcadeSortGroupRightLeft.name: ArcadeSortGroupRightLeft
ceramic.ArcadeSortGroupRightLeft.description:
ArcadeSortGroupLeftRight provides a stable implementation of merge sort through its sort
method. It should be used instead of Array.sort in cases where the order
of equal elements has to be retained on all targets.

ceramic.ArcadeSortGroupTopBottom.name: ArcadeSortGroupTopBottom
ceramic.ArcadeSortGroupTopBottom.description:
ArcadeSortGroupTopBottom provides a stable implementation of merge sort through its sort
method. It should be used instead of Array.sort in cases where the order
of equal elements has to be retained on all targets.

ceramic.AssetPathInfo.name: AssetPathInfo
ceramic.AssetPathInfo.description: Information extracted from a raw asset path

ceramic.BackgroundQueue.name: BackgroundQueue
ceramic.BackgroundQueue.description:
An utility to enqueue functions and execute them in bbackground, in a serialized way,
meaning it is garanteed that no function in this queue will be run in parallel. An enqueued
function will always be started after every previous function has finished executing.

ceramic.BezierEasing.name: BezierEasing
ceramic.BezierEasing.description:
Bezier curve easing, ported from https://github.com/gre/bezier-easing
then extended to work with both cubic and quadratic settings

ceramic.Border.name: Border
ceramic.Border.description: A rectangle visual that display a border

ceramic.ColumnLayout.name: ColumnLayout
ceramic.ColumnLayout.description:
A layout that arranges its children vertically in a single column.
This class is a LinearLayout subclass, restricted to its vertical direction.

ceramic.Component.name: Component
ceramic.Component.description:
A Component is and Entity that can be bound to another Entity.
Any Entity can be used as a Component, given that it implement Component interface.
A Component must be an Entity subclass.

ceramic.ConvertField.name: ConvertField
ceramic.ConvertField.description: Interface to convert basic type T to field type U and vice versa.

ceramic.Csv.name: Csv
ceramic.Csv.description: Utilities to parse CSV and related

ceramic.Extensions.name: Extensions
ceramic.Extensions.description: A bunch of static extensions to make life easier.

ceramic.FieldInfo.name: FieldInfo
ceramic.FieldInfo.description:
Extract field information from a given class type.
This is expected to only work with Entity subclasses marked with @editable, @fieldInfo or @autoFieldInfo
or classes using FieldInfoMacro.

ceramic.FileWatcher.name: FileWatcher
ceramic.FileWatcher.description: A file watcher for ceramic compatible with interpret.Watcher.

ceramic.Files.name: Files
ceramic.Files.description: Filesystem-related utilities. Only work on sys targets and/or nodejs depending on the methods

ceramic.Filter.name: Filter
ceramic.Filter.description:
A visuals that displays its children through a filter. A filter draws its children into a RenderTexture
allowing to process the result through a shader, apply blending or alpha on the final result...

ceramic.Fragment.name: Fragment
ceramic.Fragment.description: A fragment is a group of visuals rendered from data (.fragment file)

ceramic.Group.name: Group
ceramic.Group.description: A group of entities, which is itself an entity.

ceramic.HashedString.name: HashedString
ceramic.HashedString.description: An utility to encode strings with hashes, allowing to check their validity on decode.

ceramic.ImageView.name: ImageView
ceramic.ImageView.description: A view to display and layout images.

ceramic.InitSettings.name: InitSettings
ceramic.InitSettings.description:
Same as Settings, but for app startup (inside Project.new(settings)).
Read-only values can still
be edited at that stage.

ceramic.IntMap.name: IntMap
ceramic.IntMap.description: An object map that uses integers as key.

ceramic.Layer.name: Layer
ceramic.Layer.description: Just a regular quad (transparent by default) with a few addition to make it more convenient when used as a layer

ceramic.Lazy.name: Lazy
ceramic.Lazy.description:
Lazy allows to mark any property as lazy.
Lazy properties are initialized only at first access.

ceramic.Line.name: Line
ceramic.Line.description: Display lines composed of multiple segments, curves...

ceramic.LinearLayout.name: LinearLayout
ceramic.LinearLayout.description:
A layout that arranges its children either horizontally
in a single column or vertically in a single row.

ceramic.LowRes.name: LowRes
ceramic.LowRes.description:
A container to display visuals at low resolution,
with the possibility to use antialiasing (supersampling).

ceramic.MeshExtensions.name: MeshExtensions
ceramic.MeshExtensions.description: Static extension with additional helpers for ceramic.Mesh

ceramic.MeshPool.name: MeshPool
ceramic.MeshPool.description: An utility to reuse meshes at application level.

ceramic.ParticleItem.name: ParticleItem
ceramic.ParticleItem.description:
A particle item.
You should not instanciate this yourself as
it is managed by a Particles emitter object.

ceramic.Path.name: Path
ceramic.Path.description:
This class provides a convenient way of working with paths. It supports the
common path formats:

ceramic.PixelArt.name: PixelArt
ceramic.PixelArt.description:
A filter configured to display pixel art content.
Uses a shader to get a nicer rendering of upscaled pixel art.
Better than NEAREST or LINEAR texture filtering.
(see https://colececil.io/blog/2017/scaling-pixel-art-without-destroying-it/)

ceramic.PlatformSpecific.name: PlatformSpecific
ceramic.PlatformSpecific.description:
An internal class that encapsulate platform-specific code.
We usually want platform-specific code to be located in a backend,
but it may happen that sometimes creating a backend interface is overkill.
That's where this comes handy.

ceramic.Renderer.name: Renderer
ceramic.Renderer.description:
An implementation-independant GPU 2D renderer.
To be used in pair with a draw backend implementation.

ceramic.ReusableArray.name: ReusableArray
ceramic.ReusableArray.description:
A reusable array to use in places that need a temporary array many times.
Changing array size only increases the backing array size but never decreases it.

ceramic.RowLayout.name: RowLayout
ceramic.RowLayout.description:
A layout that arranges its children horizontally in a single row.
This class is a LinearLayout subclass, restricted to its horizontal direction.

ceramic.Runner.name: Runner
ceramic.Runner.description:
A simple Haxe class for easily running threads and calling functions on the primary thread.
from https://github.com/underscorediscovery/

ceramic.RuntimeAssets.name: RuntimeAssets
ceramic.RuntimeAssets.description:
Runtime utilities to compute asset lists/names from raw (relative) file list.
Code is very similar to AssetsMacro, but for runtime execution, with any list of asset.

ceramic.SceneSystem.name: SceneSystem
ceramic.SceneSystem.description:
System managing scenes display and lifecycle.
Use it to structure your app in different scenes.

ceramic.ScriptModule.name: ScriptModule
ceramic.ScriptModule.description:
For now, just a way to identify a script module as a type, to resolve fields dynamically from scripts.
Might be extended later to link with "script converted to haxe compiled code"

ceramic.SeedRandom.name: SeedRandom
ceramic.SeedRandom.description: Seeded random number generator to get reproducible sequences of values.

ceramic.Shape.name: Shape
ceramic.Shape.description: Draw shapes by triangulating vertices automatically, with optional holes in it.

ceramic.Shortcuts.name: Shortcuts
ceramic.Shortcuts.description:
Shortcuts adds convenience identifiers to access ceramic app, screen, ...
Use it by adding import ceramic.Shortcuts.*; in your files.

ceramic.SlotInfo.name: SlotInfo
ceramic.SlotInfo.description: An object to hold every needed info about updating a slot.

ceramic.SortVisuals.name: SortVisuals
ceramic.SortVisuals.description:
SortVisuals provides a stable implementation of merge sort through its sort
method. It should be used instead of Array.sort in cases where the order
of equal elements has to be retained on all targets.

ceramic.SortVisualsByDepth.name: SortVisualsByDepth
ceramic.SortVisualsByDepth.description:
SortVisuals provides a stable implementation of merge sort through its sort
method. It should be used instead of Array.sort in cases where the order
of equal elements has to be retained on all targets.

ceramic.SpineMontage.name: SpineMontage
ceramic.SpineMontage.description: An utility to group an pre-configure spine animations together as a single montage

ceramic.System.name: System
ceramic.System.description:
A System is an object assigned to app lifecycle and used to
do some work such as dispatching events or manipulating entities.
Systems can be ordered with order properties

ceramic.Text.name: Text
ceramic.Text.description:
A visual to layout and display text.
Works with UTF-8 strings.

ceramic.Texture.name: Texture
ceramic.Texture.description: A texture is an image ready to be drawn.

ceramic.TextureTilePacker.name: TextureTilePacker
ceramic.TextureTilePacker.description: Incremental texture tile packer that allows to alloc, release and reuse tiles as needed.

ceramic.Tilemap.name: Tilemap
ceramic.Tilemap.description:
Renders tilemap data.
Note: only ORTHOGONAL is supported

ceramic.TilemapData.name: TilemapData
ceramic.TilemapData.description:
Tilemap data.
Strongly inspired from Tiled TMX format.
(https://doc.mapeditor.org/en/stable/reference/tmx-map-format/).

ceramic.TimelineTrack.name: TimelineTrack
ceramic.TimelineTrack.description:
A track meant to be updated by a timeline.
Base implementation doesn't do much by itself.
Create subclasses to implement details

ceramic.Timelines.name: Timelines
ceramic.Timelines.description:
App-level timeline related events.
You'll only need to track these events if you want to add new types of timeline tracks & keyframes
that can be created from raw data in Fragment instances.

ceramic.Transform.name: Transform
ceramic.Transform.description:
Transform holds matrix data to make 2d rotate, translate, scale and skew transformations.
Angles are in degrees.
Representation:
| a | c | tx |
| b | d | ty |
| 0 | 0 | 1  |

ceramic.TransformPool.name: TransformPool
ceramic.TransformPool.description: An utility to reuse transform matrix object at application level.

ceramic.Triangle.name: Triangle
ceramic.Triangle.description:
A simple colored triangle, to fulfill all your triangle-shaped needs.
The triangle is facing top and fits exactly in width and height

ceramic.Triangulate.name: Triangulate
ceramic.Triangulate.description: An utility to triangulate indices from a set of vertices

ceramic.Utils.name: Utils
ceramic.Utils.description: Various utilities. Some of them are used by ceramic itself or its backends.

ceramic.Value.name: Value
ceramic.Value.description: An object that can hold any value

ceramic.ValueEntry.name: ValueEntry
ceramic.ValueEntry.description: A collection entry that can hold any value

ceramic.VisibleBounds.name: VisibleBounds
ceramic.VisibleBounds.description: An utility to display visible bounds on any visual

ceramic.Visual.name: Visual
ceramic.Visual.description:
Visuals are the building blocks to display things on screen.
A raw visual doesn't display anything but can have children
that can be more specialized visuals like Quad, Mesh or Text etc...

ceramic.AlphaColor.name: AlphaColor
ceramic.AlphaColor.description:
RGBA Color stored as integer.
Can be decomposed to Color/Int (RGB) + Float (A) and
constructed from Color/Int (RGB) + Float (A).

ceramic.AutoTileKind.name: AutoTileKind
ceramic.AutoTileKind.description: Specifies which kind of auto tiling to use with AutoTiler component

ceramic.Color.name: Color
ceramic.Color.description: Class representing a color, based on Int. Provides a variety of methods for creating and converting colors.

ceramic.Either.name: Either
ceramic.Either.description:
Useful to limit a Dynamic function argument's type to the specified
type parameters. This does NOT make the use of Dynamic type-safe in
any way (the underlying type is still Dynamic and Std.isOfType() checks +
casts are necessary).

ceramic.ReadOnlyArray.name: ReadOnlyArray
ceramic.ReadOnlyArray.description:
Copyright (c) 2012-2017 Alexander Gordeyko <axgord@gmail.com>. All rights reserved.

 permitted provided that the following conditions are met:

 ANY THEORY OF LIABILITY, WHETHER IN CONTRACT, STRICT LIABILITY, OR TORT (INCLUDING
 NEGLIGENCE OR OTHERWISE) ARISING IN ANY WAY OUT OF THE USE OF THIS SOFTWARE, EVEN IF
 ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGE.</axgord@gmail.com>

ceramic.ChildrenDepth.name: ChildrenDepth
ceramic.ChildrenDepth.description: Control how children depth is sorted.

ceramic.ParticlesLaunchMode.name: ParticlesLaunchMode
ceramic.ParticlesLaunchMode.description:
How particles should be launched. If CIRCLE, particles will use launchAngle and speed.
Otherwise, particles will just use velocityX and velocityY.

ceramic.ParticlesStatus.name: ParticlesStatus
ceramic.ParticlesStatus.description: Which status a Particles emitter object has.

clay.BackgroundQueue.name: BackgroundQueue
clay.BackgroundQueue.description:
An utility to enqueue functions and execute them in bbackground, in a serialized way,
meaning it is garanteed that no function in this queue will be run in parallel. An enqueued
function will always be started after every previous function has finished executing.

clay.Extensions.name: Extensions
clay.Extensions.description: A bunch of static extensions to make life easier.

clay.RenderConfig.name: RenderConfig
clay.RenderConfig.description: Config specific to the rendering context that would be used when creating windows

clay.RenderConfigOpenGL.name: RenderConfigOpenGL
clay.RenderConfigOpenGL.description:
Config specific to an OpenGL rendering context.
Note that these are hints to the system,
you must always check the values after initializing
for what you actually received. The OS/driver decides.

clay.RenderConfigWebGL.name: RenderConfigWebGL
clay.RenderConfigWebGL.description:
Config specific to a WebGL rendering context.
See: https://www.khronos.org/registry/webgl/specs/latest/1.0/#WEBGLCONTEXTATTRIBUTES

clay.Runner.name: Runner
clay.Runner.description:
A simple Haxe class for easily running threads and calling functions on the primary thread.
from https://github.com/underscorediscovery/

clay.WindowConfig.name: WindowConfig
clay.WindowConfig.description: Window configuration information for creating windows

clay.OpenGLProfile.name: OpenGLProfile
clay.OpenGLProfile.description: A type of OpenGL context profile to request. see RenderConfigOpenGL for info

clay.TextEventType.name: TextEventType
clay.TextEventType.description: A text specific event event type

elements.Im.name: Im
elements.Im.description:
API inspired by Dear ImGui,
but using ceramic elements UI,
making it work with any ceramic target

elements.TabFocus.name: TabFocus
elements.TabFocus.description: Update field focus from tab key events

elements.WindowItem.name: WindowItem
elements.WindowItem.description:
A simple class to hold window item data.
The same class is used for every window item kind so
that it's easier to recycle it and avoid allocating
too much data at every frame.

nape.TArray.name: TArray
nape.TArray.description: Platform specific Array type. For flash10+ This is flash.Vector<T>, and otherwise Array<T>.

spine.AlphaTimeline.name: AlphaTimeline
spine.AlphaTimeline.description: Changes the alpha for a slot's {@link Slot#getColor()}.

spine.Animation.name: Animation
spine.Animation.description: Stores a list of timelines to animate a skeleton's pose over time.

spine.AnimationState.name: AnimationState
spine.AnimationState.description:
Applies animations over time, queues animations for later playback, mixes (crossfading) between animations, and applies
multiple animations on top of each other (layering).

See Applying Animations in the Spine Runtimes Guide.

spine.AnimationStateData.name: AnimationStateData
spine.AnimationStateData.description: Stores mix (crossfade) durations to be applied when {@link AnimationState} animations are changed.

spine.AnimationStateListener.name: AnimationStateListener
spine.AnimationStateListener.description:
The interface to implement for receiving TrackEntry events. It is always safe to call AnimationState methods when receiving
events.

See TrackEntry {@link TrackEntry#setListener(AnimationStateListener)} and AnimationState
{@link AnimationState#addListener(AnimationStateListener)}.

spine.Bone.name: Bone
spine.Bone.description:
Stores a bone's current pose.

A bone has a local transform which is used to compute its world transform. A bone also has an applied transform, which is a
local transform that can be applied to compute the world transform. The local transform and applied transform may differ if a
constraint or application code modifies the world transform after it was computed from the local transform.

spine.BoneData.name: BoneData
spine.BoneData.description: Stores the setup pose for a {@link Bone}.

spine.BoneTimeline.name: BoneTimeline
spine.BoneTimeline.description: An interface for timelines which change the property of a bone.

spine.ConstraintData.name: ConstraintData
spine.ConstraintData.description: The base class for all constraint datas.

spine.CurveTimeline.name: CurveTimeline
spine.CurveTimeline.description: The base class for timelines that interpolate between frame values using stepped, linear, or a Bezier curve.

spine.CurveTimeline1.name: CurveTimeline1
spine.CurveTimeline1.description: The base class for a {@link CurveTimeline} that sets one property.

spine.CurveTimeline2.name: CurveTimeline2
spine.CurveTimeline2.description: The base class for a {@link CurveTimeline} which sets two properties.

spine.DeformTimeline.name: DeformTimeline
spine.DeformTimeline.description: Changes a slot's {@link Slot#getDeform()} to deform a {@link VertexAttachment}.

spine.Event.name: Event
spine.Event.description:
Stores the current pose values for an {@link Event}.

See Timeline
{@link Timeline#apply(Skeleton, float, float, com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Array, float, com.esotericsoftware.spine.Animation.MixBlend, com.esotericsoftware.spine.Animation.MixDirection)},
AnimationStateListener {@link AnimationStateListener#event(com.esotericsoftware.spine.AnimationState.TrackEntry, Event)}, and
Events in the Spine User Guide.

spine.EventData.name: EventData
spine.EventData.description:
Stores the setup pose values for an {@link Event}.

See Events in the Spine User Guide.

spine.EventTimeline.name: EventTimeline
spine.EventTimeline.description: Fires an {@link Event} when specific animation times are reached.

spine.IkConstraint.name: IkConstraint
spine.IkConstraint.description:
Stores the current pose for an IK constraint. An IK constraint adjusts the rotation of 1 or 2 constrained bones so the tip of
the last bone is as close to the target bone as possible.

See IK constraints in the Spine User Guide.

spine.IkConstraintData.name: IkConstraintData
spine.IkConstraintData.description:
Stores the setup pose for an {@link IkConstraint}.

See IK constraints in the Spine User Guide.

spine.IkConstraintTimeline.name: IkConstraintTimeline
spine.IkConstraintTimeline.description:
Changes an IK constraint's {@link IkConstraint#getMix()}, {@link IkConstraint#getSoftness()},
{@link IkConstraint#getBendDirection()}, {@link IkConstraint#getStretch()}, and {@link IkConstraint#getCompress()}.

spine.PathConstraint.name: PathConstraint
spine.PathConstraint.description:
Stores the current pose for a path constraint. A path constraint adjusts the rotation, translation, and scale of the
constrained bones so they follow a {@link PathAttachment}.

See Path constraints in the Spine User Guide.

spine.PathConstraintData.name: PathConstraintData
spine.PathConstraintData.description:
Stores the setup pose for a {@link PathConstraint}.

See Path constraints in the Spine User Guide.

spine.PathConstraintMixTimeline.name: PathConstraintMixTimeline
spine.PathConstraintMixTimeline.description:
Changes a transform constraint's {@link PathConstraint#getMixRotate()}, {@link PathConstraint#getMixX()}, and
{@link PathConstraint#getMixY()}.

spine.RGB2Timeline.name: RGB2Timeline
spine.RGB2Timeline.description: Changes the RGB for a slot's {@link Slot#getColor()} and {@link Slot#getDarkColor()} for two color tinting.

spine.RGBA2Timeline.name: RGBA2Timeline
spine.RGBA2Timeline.description: Changes a slot's {@link Slot#getColor()} and {@link Slot#getDarkColor()} for two color tinting.

spine.RGBTimeline.name: RGBTimeline
spine.RGBTimeline.description: Changes the RGB for a slot's {@link Slot#getColor()}.

spine.ScaleTimeline.name: ScaleTimeline
spine.ScaleTimeline.description: Changes a bone's local {@link Bone#getScaleX()} and {@link Bone#getScaleY()}.

spine.ShearTimeline.name: ShearTimeline
spine.ShearTimeline.description: Changes a bone's local {@link Bone#getShearX()} and {@link Bone#getShearY()}.

spine.Skeleton.name: Skeleton
spine.Skeleton.description:
Stores the current pose for a skeleton.

See Instance objects in the Spine
Runtimes Guide.

spine.SkeletonBounds.name: SkeletonBounds
spine.SkeletonBounds.description:
Collects each visible {@link BoundingBoxAttachment} and computes the world vertices for its polygon. The polygon vertices are
provided along with convenience methods for doing hit detection.

spine.SkeletonData.name: SkeletonData
spine.SkeletonData.description:
Stores the setup pose and all of the stateless data for a skeleton.

See Data objects in the Spine Runtimes
Guide.

spine.SkeletonJson.name: SkeletonJson
spine.SkeletonJson.description:
Loads skeleton data in the Spine JSON format.

JSON is human readable but the binary format is much smaller on disk and faster to load. See {@link SkeletonBinary}.

See Spine JSON format and
JSON and binary data in the Spine
Runtimes Guide.

spine.SkeletonLoader.name: SkeletonLoader
spine.SkeletonLoader.description:
Base class for loading skeleton data from a file.

See JSON and binary data in the
Spine Runtimes Guide.

spine.Skin.name: Skin
spine.Skin.description:
Stores attachments by slot index and attachment name.

See SkeletonData {@link SkeletonData#defaultSkin}, Skeleton {@link Skeleton#skin}, and
Runtime skins in the Spine Runtimes Guide.

spine.SkinEntry.name: SkinEntry
spine.SkinEntry.description: Stores an entry in the skin consisting of the slot index and the attachment name.

spine.Slot.name: Slot
spine.Slot.description:
Stores a slot's current pose. Slots organize attachments for {@link Skeleton#drawOrder} purposes and provide a place to store
state for an attachment. State cannot be stored in an attachment itself because attachments are stateless and may be shared
across multiple skeletons.

spine.SlotData.name: SlotData
spine.SlotData.description: Stores the setup pose for a {@link Slot}.

spine.SlotTimeline.name: SlotTimeline
spine.SlotTimeline.description: An interface for timelines which change the property of a slot.

spine.Timeline.name: Timeline
spine.Timeline.description: The base class for all timelines.

spine.TrackEntry.name: TrackEntry
spine.TrackEntry.description:
Stores settings and other state for the playback of an animation on an {@link AnimationState} track.

References to a track entry must not be kept after the {@link AnimationStateListener#dispose(TrackEntry)} event occurs.

spine.TransformConstraint.name: TransformConstraint
spine.TransformConstraint.description:
Stores the current pose for a transform constraint. A transform constraint adjusts the world transform of the constrained
bones to match that of the target bone.

See Transform constraints in the Spine User Guide.

spine.TransformConstraintData.name: TransformConstraintData
spine.TransformConstraintData.description:
Stores the setup pose for a {@link TransformConstraint}.

See Transform constraints in the Spine User Guide.

spine.TransformConstraintTimeline.name: TransformConstraintTimeline
spine.TransformConstraintTimeline.description:
Changes a transform constraint's {@link TransformConstraint#getMixRotate()}, {@link TransformConstraint#getMixX()},
{@link TransformConstraint#getMixY()}, {@link TransformConstraint#getMixScaleX()},
{@link TransformConstraint#getMixScaleY()}, and {@link TransformConstraint#getMixShearY()}.

spine.TranslateTimeline.name: TranslateTimeline
spine.TranslateTimeline.description: Changes a bone's local {@link Bone#getX()} and {@link Bone#getY()}.

spine.Updatable.name: Updatable
spine.Updatable.description: The interface for items updated by {@link Skeleton#updateWorldTransform()}.

spine.BlendMode.name: BlendMode
spine.BlendMode.description: Determines how images are blended with existing pixels when drawn.

spine.MixBlend.name: MixBlend
spine.MixBlend.description:
Controls how timeline values are mixed with setup pose values or current pose values when a timeline is applied with
alpha < 1.

See Timeline {@link Timeline#apply(Skeleton, float, float, Array, float, MixBlend, MixDirection)}.

spine.MixDirection.name: MixDirection
spine.MixDirection.description:
Indicates whether a timeline's alpha is mixing out over time toward 0 (the setup or current pose value) or
mixing in toward 1 (the timeline's value). Some timelines use this to decide how values are applied.

See Timeline {@link Timeline#apply(Skeleton, float, float, Array, float, MixBlend, MixDirection)}.

spine.PositionMode.name: PositionMode
spine.PositionMode.description:
Controls how the first bone is positioned along the path.

See Position mode in the Spine User Guide.

spine.RotateMode.name: RotateMode
spine.RotateMode.description:
Controls how bones are rotated, translated, and scaled to match the path.

See Rotate mode in the Spine User Guide.

spine.SpacingMode.name: SpacingMode
spine.SpacingMode.description:
Controls how bones after the first bone are positioned along the path.

See Spacing mode in the Spine User Guide.

spine.TransformMode.name: TransformMode
spine.TransformMode.description: Determines how a bone inherits world transforms from parent bones.

tracker.DynamicEvents.name: DynamicEvents
tracker.DynamicEvents.description:
Fire and listen to dynamic events. Works similarly to static events, but dynamic.
If you can know the event names at compile time, using static events (@event function myEvent();) is preferred.

tracker.EventDispatcher.name: EventDispatcher
tracker.EventDispatcher.description:
Event dispatcher used by DynamicEvents and Events macro as an alternative implementation
that doesn't require to add a lot of methods on classes with events.
This is basically the same code as what is statically generated by Events macro,
but made dynamic and usable for any type.
This is not really supposed to be used as is as it is pretty low-level.

tracker.Events.name: Events
tracker.Events.description:
Events allows to add strictly typed events to classes.
Generates related methods: on|once|off|emit{EventName}()

tracker.Extensions.name: Extensions
tracker.Extensions.description: A bunch of static extensions to make life easier.

tracker.Observable.name: Observable
tracker.Observable.description: Observable allows to observe properties of an object.

tracker.SerializeModel.name: SerializeModel
tracker.SerializeModel.description: Utility to serialize a model object (and its children) continuously and efficiently

clay.audio.AudioData.name: AudioData
clay.audio.AudioData.description:
An audio data object contains information about audio samples or streams, ready to be used.
AudioData objects typically come from the app.assets.audio API or app.audio.module.data_from_path,
since the implemenation details of decoding audio and streams are module level implementation details.
This is stored by AudioSource and AssetAudio objects for example.

clay.audio.AudioFormat.name: AudioFormat
clay.audio.AudioFormat.description: The type of format data for audio

clay.audio.AudioHandle.name: AudioHandle
clay.audio.AudioHandle.description: An audio handle for tracking audio instances

nape.callbacks.BodyCallback.name: BodyCallback
nape.callbacks.BodyCallback.description:
Callback object for Body type events.

This, like all other callback objects are automatically reused
and you should not keep any reference to them.

nape.callbacks.BodyListener.name: BodyListener
nape.callbacks.BodyListener.description:
Event listener for Body type events.

The events that can be caught are WAKE and SLEEP type events.
Theses listeners will only operate on Bodys, not Interactors in general.

nape.callbacks.Callback.name: Callback
nape.callbacks.Callback.description:
Base type for Callback event objects.

Callback objects are automatically reused and you should not keep references
to them.

nape.callbacks.CbEvent.name: CbEvent
nape.callbacks.CbEvent.description: Enumeration of possible callback event types.

nape.callbacks.CbType.name: CbType
nape.callbacks.CbType.description:
Callback Type applied to Interactors and Constraints.

Callback types are ranged over by listeners.

nape.callbacks.CbTypeIterator.name: CbTypeIterator
nape.callbacks.CbTypeIterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.callbacks.CbTypeList.name: CbTypeList
nape.callbacks.CbTypeList.description: Nape list of CbType type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.callbacks.ConstraintCallback.name: ConstraintCallback
nape.callbacks.ConstraintCallback.description:
Callback object for Constraint type events.

This, like all other callback objects are automatically reused
and you should not keep any reference to them.

nape.callbacks.ConstraintListener.name: ConstraintListener
nape.callbacks.ConstraintListener.description:
Event listener for Constraint type events.

The events that can be caught are WAKE, SLEEP and BREAK type events.
Theses listeners will only operate on Constraints.

nape.callbacks.InteractionCallback.name: InteractionCallback
nape.callbacks.InteractionCallback.description:
Callback object for Interaction type events.

This, like all other callback objects are automatically reused
and you should not keep any reference to them.

nape.callbacks.InteractionListener.name: InteractionListener
nape.callbacks.InteractionListener.description: Event listener for Interaction type events. Interaction type events can occur between any two Interactors (whether they be Shapes, Bodys, Compounds or a mix thereof). The events that can be caught are BEGIN, ONGOING, and END type events. Theses listeners will operate between pairs of Interactors.

nape.callbacks.Listener.name: Listener
nape.callbacks.Listener.description: Base type for all Nape callback listeners.

nape.callbacks.ListenerIterator.name: ListenerIterator
nape.callbacks.ListenerIterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.callbacks.ListenerList.name: ListenerList
nape.callbacks.ListenerList.description: Nape list of Listener type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.callbacks.OptionType.name: OptionType

nape.callbacks.PreCallback.name: PreCallback
nape.callbacks.PreCallback.description:
Callback object for Pre-Interaction type events.

This, like all other callback objects are automatically reused
and you should not keep any reference to them.

nape.callbacks.PreFlag.name: PreFlag
nape.callbacks.PreFlag.description:
Enumeration of interaction states for arbiters. These values are returned
by PreListener callback handlers.

nape.callbacks.PreListener.name: PreListener
nape.callbacks.PreListener.description:
Event listener for Pre-Interaction type events.

Pre-Interaction type events can occur between any two Interactors (whether they
be Shapes, Bodys, Compounds or a mix thereof).

nape.constraint.AngleJoint.name: AngleJoint
nape.constraint.AngleJoint.description:
AngleJoint constraining the relative angles of two Bodies.

The equation for this constraint is:
jointMin <= ratio * body2.rotation - body1.rotation <= jointMax

nape.constraint.Constraint.name: Constraint
nape.constraint.Constraint.description: Base type for all Nape joints and constraints

nape.constraint.ConstraintIterator.name: ConstraintIterator
nape.constraint.ConstraintIterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.constraint.ConstraintList.name: ConstraintList
nape.constraint.ConstraintList.description: Nape list of Constraint type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.constraint.DistanceJoint.name: DistanceJoint
nape.constraint.DistanceJoint.description:
DistanceJoint limiting the distance between two local anchor points of Bodies.

The equation for this constraint could be written like:
jointMin <= distance(body2.localPointToWorld(anchor2), body1.localPointToWorld(anchor1)) <= jointMax

This joint is not designed to work when  jointMin = jointMax = 0  and constraint is
stiff. In this instance you should use a PivotJoint instead.

nape.constraint.LineJoint.name: LineJoint
nape.constraint.LineJoint.description: LineJoint constraining anchor of one body, to a line segment of the other. The equation for this constraint could be written like:

nape.constraint.MotorJoint.name: MotorJoint
nape.constraint.MotorJoint.description:
MotorJoint constraining the angular velocities of two bodies

The equation for this constraint is:
(ratio * body2.angularVel) - body1.angularVel = rate

This constraint operates only on the velocities of objects.

nape.constraint.PivotJoint.name: PivotJoint
nape.constraint.PivotJoint.description:
PivotJoint constraining two anchors points of bodies to be equal.

The equation for this constraint is:
body2.localPointToWorld(anchor2) = body1.localPointToWorld(anchor1)

You may view this constraint as being equal to the DistanceJoint constraint
when both its jointMin and jointMax are exactly 0 (In such a case a
DistanceJoint becomes degenerate). Compared to the DistanceJoint this is
a 2 dimensional constraint.

nape.constraint.PulleyJoint.name: PulleyJoint
nape.constraint.PulleyJoint.description:
PulleyJoint limiting the weighted sum of distances between 2 pairs of 4 local anchor points of Bodies.

The equation for this constraint could be written like:
jointMin <= distance(body2.localPointToWorld(anchor2), body1.localPointToWorld(anchor1))
+ ratio * distance(body4.localPointToWorld(anchor4), body3.localPointToWorld(anchor3)) <= jointMax

This joint is not designed to work when either of these pairs achieves a distance of 0, it will still work
but may not be entirely ideal.
!1* * This constraint can be used in a full 4-body set up, or a 3-body set up or a 2-body set up permitting
any arrangement as long as body1 != body2 and body3 != body4

nape.constraint.UserConstraint.name: UserConstraint
nape.constraint.UserConstraint.description:
UserConstraint providing a low-level API for user-defined Constraints.

This API is intended to be powerful enough to model any constraint that
Nape can handle, but not so low level as to be completely prohibitive.

For instance, things like soft-constraints are automatically provided
by this API.

Working with this API will require mathematical skills. A full manual
for this API is provided at: http://napephys.com/help/Constraints.pdf

You may also be interested in the nape-symbolic module that is available
on github/haxelib/nape downloads. Which provides a run-time compiled DSL
using this API to make prototyping (or creating non-performance critical)
user-defined constraints simple without the need for great mathematical
skills as well as being much quicker to work with.

nape.constraint.WeldJoint.name: WeldJoint
nape.constraint.WeldJoint.description:
WeldJoint constraining two bodies to be exactly locked together.

The equation for this constraint is:
[ body2.localPointToWorld(anchor2) ] = [ body1.localPointToWorld(anchor1) ]
[          body2.rotation          ]   [      body1.rotation + phase      ]

This constraint is equivalent to using a PivotJoint and AngleJoint
together except that it is solved as a single constraint and thus
will be more stable.

This constraint is 3 dimensional.

Although this constraint is very stable, if you chain bodies together
using this constraint, you should except to see a small amount of rotation
about the anchor points so you should chose them accordingly.

nape.geom.AABB.name: AABB
nape.geom.AABB.description:
Axis Aligned Bounding Box (AABB)

Note that in many cases of an AABB object being returned by a Nape function
the AABB object will be marked internally as an 'immutable' AABB. This will
always be documented and trying to mutate such an AABB will result in an
error being thrown.

nape.geom.ConvexResult.name: ConvexResult
nape.geom.ConvexResult.description:
Class representing the results of a convex cast operation.

These objects are allocated from an object pool and can
be released back to that pool by calling its dispose method.

nape.geom.ConvexResultIterator.name: ConvexResultIterator
nape.geom.ConvexResultIterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.geom.ConvexResultList.name: ConvexResultList
nape.geom.ConvexResultList.description: Nape list of ConvexResult type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.geom.Geom.name: Geom
nape.geom.Geom.description: Geom class provides interface to collision detection routines in nape.

nape.geom.GeomPoly.name: GeomPoly
nape.geom.GeomPoly.description:
Polygon class with various geometric methods

This class represents a general Polygon, rather than the Polygon class
which is physics shape.

Internally this polygon is stored as a circularly linked list of special
vertex types that are exposed via a Vec2 that is lazily constructed whenever
necessary to the API.

nape.geom.GeomPolyIterator.name: GeomPolyIterator
nape.geom.GeomPolyIterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.geom.GeomPolyList.name: GeomPolyList
nape.geom.GeomPolyList.description: Nape list of GeomPoly type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.geom.GeomVertexIterator.name: GeomVertexIterator
nape.geom.GeomVertexIterator.description:
Haxe compatible iterator over vertices of GeomPoly.

Vec2's intrinsically tied to the vertices are exposed through
the iterator which does not modify the state of the polygon.

nape.geom.MarchingSquares.name: MarchingSquares

nape.geom.Mat23.name: Mat23
nape.geom.Mat23.description:
2D Matrix class representing affine transformations:
[ a  b  tx ]
[ c  d  ty ]
[ 0  0  1  ]

nape.geom.MatMN.name: MatMN
nape.geom.MatMN.description:
A general MxN dimensional matrix.

This object is not often used in Nape :)

nape.geom.Ray.name: Ray
nape.geom.Ray.description: Parametrically defined ray used in ray casting functions.

nape.geom.RayResult.name: RayResult
nape.geom.RayResult.description:
Class representing the results of a ray cast operation.

These objects are allocated from an object pool and can
be released back to that pool by calling its dispose method.

nape.geom.RayResultIterator.name: RayResultIterator
nape.geom.RayResultIterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.geom.RayResultList.name: RayResultList
nape.geom.RayResultList.description: Nape list of RayResult type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.geom.Vec2.name: Vec2
nape.geom.Vec2.description:
2 Dimensional vector.

Note that in many cases of a Vec2 object being returned by a Nape function
the Vec2 object will be marked internally as an 'immutable' Vec2. This will
always be documented and trying to mutate such a Vec2 will result in an
error being thrown.

Vec2 objects can make use of a global object pool, attempting to make use
of a disposed Vec2 will also result in an error with the object pool
working in a FILO order to increase the likelihood of such misuse being
caught.

Additionally Vec2 objects can be created as 'weak'. Passing a weak Vec2 to
any Nape function as an argument will result in the automatic disposal of
the Vec2 once the method has finished with it. There may be exceptions to
this rule which will also be documented; a notable case being the appending
of a weak Vec2 to a Nape Vec2List in which case the disposal of the weak
Vec2 is performed when that Vec2List is handed to a Nape function instead.

Example:
var vertices = Polygon.box(20, 20, true);
var polygon = new Polygon(vertices);

In this example, passing true to the Polygon.box method means
that we will be returned a Vec2List containing only 'weak' Vec2s. Upon
passing this Vec2List to the Polygon constructor, all of the Vec2s from
that list will be automatically disposed.

nape.geom.Vec2Iterator.name: Vec2Iterator
nape.geom.Vec2Iterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.geom.Vec2List.name: Vec2List
nape.geom.Vec2List.description: Nape list of Vec2 type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.geom.Vec3.name: Vec3
nape.geom.Vec3.description:
A 3 dimensional vector object.

In many instances a Vec3 will be accessible from Nape which is marked
as immutable, these cases will be documented and modifying such a Vec3
will result in an error.

nape.geom.Winding.name: Winding
nape.geom.Winding.description:
Enumeration represents the winding of a Polygon.

To appreciate what the winding of a polygon means, think of a polygon who's
vertices are the numbers on a clock face.

nape.geom.IsoFunctionDef.name: IsoFunctionDef
nape.geom.IsoFunctionDef.description:
For 'flash' targets only.

Iso-functions for MarchingSquares must be given
as an object implementing this IsoFunction interface. This is for
reasons of avoiding excessive memory allocations that occur through
automatic boxing of arguments/return values when using function values.

Since iso-functions may be called 10,000's of times per-invocation of
marching-squares, this can quickly accumulate into a lot of GC activity.

nape.phys.Body.name: Body
nape.phys.Body.description: Class representing a physics Rigid Body.

nape.phys.BodyIterator.name: BodyIterator
nape.phys.BodyIterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.phys.BodyList.name: BodyList
nape.phys.BodyList.description: Nape list of Body type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.phys.Compound.name: Compound
nape.phys.Compound.description: Compound represents a grouping of physics objects into a single object. This compound owns its constituents and works in the callback system and with respect to adding/removing from a Space as a single object.

nape.phys.CompoundIterator.name: CompoundIterator
nape.phys.CompoundIterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.phys.CompoundList.name: CompoundList
nape.phys.CompoundList.description: Nape list of Compound type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.phys.FluidProperties.name: FluidProperties
nape.phys.FluidProperties.description: FluidProperties providing shared parameters for fluid interaction.

nape.phys.GravMassMode.name: GravMassMode
nape.phys.GravMassMode.description: Enumeration of GravMassMode values for a Body.

nape.phys.InertiaMode.name: InertiaMode
nape.phys.InertiaMode.description: Enumeration of InertiaMode values for a Body.

nape.phys.InteractorIterator.name: InteractorIterator
nape.phys.InteractorIterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.phys.InteractorList.name: InteractorList
nape.phys.InteractorList.description: Nape list of Interactor type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.phys.MassMode.name: MassMode
nape.phys.MassMode.description: Enumeration of MassMode values for a Body.

nape.phys.Material.name: Material
nape.phys.Material.description: Material property providing physical attributes to a Shape.

nape.shape.Edge.name: Edge
nape.shape.Edge.description: Edge class providing internal details of Polygon.

nape.shape.EdgeIterator.name: EdgeIterator
nape.shape.EdgeIterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.shape.EdgeList.name: EdgeList
nape.shape.EdgeList.description: Nape list of Edge type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.shape.Polygon.name: Polygon
nape.shape.Polygon.description:
Polygon subtype of Shape.

Can be used to simulate any convex polygon.

nape.shape.ShapeIterator.name: ShapeIterator
nape.shape.ShapeIterator.description: Haxe Iterator compatible iterator over Nape list.

nape.shape.ShapeList.name: ShapeList
nape.shape.ShapeList.description: Nape list of Shape type objects Internally this list is at present implemented as a linked list with object pooled nodes and iterators with various fast paths made for standard access patterns (For instance accessing successive elements runs in constant time when using random access functions) Iteration of this list can be done in various ways, but the preferred way on all targets, is through use of the foreach function: list.foreach(function (obj) { }); This method is inlined so that in haxe no closure will need to be created. In AS3, a closure would need to be created in general, so for performance reasons you 'may' choose to use iteration as follows: for (var i:int = 0; i < list.length; i++) {

nape.shape.ValidationResult.name: ValidationResult
nape.shape.ValidationResult.description: Enumeration of validation results for a Polygon.

nape.space.Broadphase.name: Broadphase
nape.space.Broadphase.description: Enumeration of available broadphase collision types that Spaces may use.

nape.space.Space.name: Space
nape.space.Space.description: The heart of all Nape simulations.

nape.util.Debug.name: Debug
nape.util.Debug.description:
Debug class providing general utilities

Also serves as the base type for Debug draws.

spine.attachments.AtlasAttachmentLoader.name: AtlasAttachmentLoader
spine.attachments.AtlasAttachmentLoader.description:
An {@link AttachmentLoader} that configures attachments using texture regions from an {@link Atlas}.

See Loading skeleton data in the
Spine Runtimes Guide.

spine.attachments.Attachment.name: Attachment
spine.attachments.Attachment.description: The base class for all attachments.

spine.attachments.AttachmentLoader.name: AttachmentLoader
spine.attachments.AttachmentLoader.description:
The interface which can be implemented to customize creating and populating attachments.

See Loading skeleton data in the Spine
Runtimes Guide.

spine.attachments.BoundingBoxAttachment.name: BoundingBoxAttachment
spine.attachments.BoundingBoxAttachment.description:
An attachment with vertices that make up a polygon. Can be used for hit detection, creating physics bodies, spawning particle
effects, and more.

See {@link SkeletonBounds} and Bounding Boxes in the Spine User
Guide.

spine.attachments.ClippingAttachment.name: ClippingAttachment
spine.attachments.ClippingAttachment.description: An attachment with vertices that make up a polygon used for clipping the rendering of other attachments.

spine.attachments.MeshAttachment.name: MeshAttachment
spine.attachments.MeshAttachment.description:
An attachment that displays a textured mesh. A mesh has hull vertices and internal vertices within the hull. Holes are not
supported. Each vertex has UVs (texture coordinates) and triangles are used to map an image on to the mesh.

See Mesh attachments in the Spine User Guide.

spine.attachments.PathAttachment.name: PathAttachment
spine.attachments.PathAttachment.description:
An attachment whose vertices make up a composite Bezier curve.

See {@link PathConstraint} and Paths in the Spine User Guide.

spine.attachments.PointAttachment.name: PointAttachment
spine.attachments.PointAttachment.description:
An attachment which is a single point and a rotation. This can be used to spawn projectiles, particles, etc. A bone can be
used in similar ways, but a PointAttachment is slightly less expensive to compute and can be hidden, shown, and placed in a
skin.

See Point Attachments in the Spine User Guide.

spine.attachments.RegionAttachment.name: RegionAttachment
spine.attachments.RegionAttachment.description:
An attachment that displays a textured quadrilateral.

See Region attachments in the Spine User Guide.

spine.attachments.VertexAttachment.name: VertexAttachment
spine.attachments.VertexAttachment.description:
Base class for an attachment with vertices that are transformed by one or more bones and can be deformed by a slot's
{@link Slot#getDeform()}.

spine.support.utils.Poolable.name: Poolable
spine.support.utils.Poolable.description: Objects implementing this interface will have {@link #reset()} called when passed to {@link Pool#free(Object)}.

spine.support.utils.Either.name: Either
spine.support.utils.Either.description:
Useful to limit a Dynamic function argument's type to the specified
type parameters. This does NOT make the use of Dynamic type-safe in
any way (the underlying type is still Dynamic and Std.isOfType() checks +
casts are necessary).
